Sorry!
I forgot to mention Dhananjay's point:

The resource is "owned" by =
the server space (not by a particular server) and that resource, modeled in=
 a state machine (which would be metadata), may change its rules at any tim=
e. Thus, it makes perfect sense what Dhananjay mentions about a set of part=
icular "legal" transitions in a given point of time (or state). That set of=
 transitions is the one offered by the server to the client (that list or U=
RLs and actions). 

Still, that list is inferred by the server at hand from=
 the resource's actual state and metadata, and sent back to client. It is n=
ever maintained as a state in one particular server. 

In that way, if the =
rules change, the next server that receives a request for legal actions, wi=
ll build the list using the new rules, and the client will have an automati=
c, on the spot, application update. That is why knowing the operations out =
of band is not good for app maintainability. And of course, server may need=
 those rules too to avoid crazy, out of place clients trying to post illega=
l actions.

Cheers again!

William Martinez Pomares
